div.head: THE WOMAN IN RED !
div.p: A New Drama of powerful interest, partly adapted and altered from the French Piece of “La Tireuse des Cartes,” by STIRLING COYNE, Esq.—The New Scenery by Mr. Frederick Fenton.

div.head: PROLOGUE (France, 1670). The Seal of Death!
div.p: MARGUERITE D'ARBEL'S COTTAGE, VILLAGE OF CASTELLAN, FOOT OF THE FRENCH ALPS.

div.head: ACT II.—(ITALY, 1686). THE TWO MOTHERS
div.p: A STREET, NEAR THE PIAZZA SAN LORENZO.

div.head: ACT III—(VENICE, 1687). THE HEART'S VICTORY!
div.p: Overlooking the Guideca and S. Giorgio Maggiore.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Scene.—The Cottage of Marguerite D'Arbel in the Village of Castellan in the Lower Alps, on the French side of the Italian frontier. The Scene represents an Apartment on the ground floor of the cottage; door of entrance, L. flat, back; a large window, R. C. flat, through which is seen an Alpine landscape; projecting chimney, and hearth on which a wood fire is burning, L. 2 E.; a staircase leading to Marguerite's apartment, R. 3 E.; a cradle, L., near the fire-place; a cupboard with large door to turn back, L. U. E.; rustic furniture; a heavy table, C.
On the rising of the curtain, Ninon is discovered kneeling by the cradle, L., singing a little cradle song.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Ah, bless her heart! that long sleep has done her good.
sp.stage: Marguerite enters from her chamber at the head of the stairs, R., and descends while Ninon sings.

sp.speaker: Marguerite.
sp.p: How kind of you, Ninon, to leave your work and come to help me, to-day, when I am so busy preparing for the return of my husband, whose ship has arrived at Marseilles. I expect my dear little Neomi's parents also; they are coming this morning to take this child. Is the darling awake yet?

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Yes; she has just opened her bright eyes, and looks beautiful as an angel.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Sweet angel! It will pain my heart to part with one I love as dearly almost as my own child.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Neomi's parents are Jews—are they not?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes; Jews from Marseilles, who on the death of a rich relative were compelled to make a sudden journey last autumn to Hamburgh, to take possession of the enormous wealth which had been bequeathed to them.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: And litle Neomi was left in your care?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: She was too young and fragile to bear the long journey, so I took charge of her, and have given her plenty of fresh air and goat's milk.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p:
You, and the air, and the goat have done your duty,
for the dear child is a picture of health. You'll be very lonely without her, but you have Claude to comfort you, and keep you from grieving too much after little Neomi. Claude grows a fine boy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes; he's a dear little fellow. Do you know, although he has only turned six, he already speaks of going to sea with his father?

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: I like the spirit of the child, and if I were you I'd let him follow his inclination. Who knows but some day he may rise to be an admiral or a boatswain.
sp.stage: (Hubert Malisset appears outside window at back, which is partly open)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I should like to see him choose some other profession than the sea.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Why, Marguerite, you married a sailor, yourself! Maurice D'Arbel is a good husband, and you are a happy woman.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: The wife of a sailor can never be happy; long absences and anxious looking for the loved one's return, make many blanks in her life. When Maurice left me to go this last voyage, I had a strange foreboding we should never meet again.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: But he has returned safe, and your fears are over.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.stage: (perceiving Hubert's face at the window—screams, then grasping Ninon's arm)
sp.p: There—look—that face! (Hubert disappears) A-ah!

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis gone! (sinks back nearly fainting) Twice already, within the last three days, have I beheld those features.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: You tremble, Marguerite—and your face is pale as ashes, what has agitated you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Do not question me. (hiding her face in her hands) Yet why should I conceal from you a secret which is heavy at my heart. You are kind and affectionate and will pity me for the one fault of my life. Let me sit where my eyes may not be turned towards the window—I dare not look that way. (she sits, L. C., with her back towards the window, Ninon sits beside her, L. at her feet) Fifteen years ago—a regiment was quartered in the villages of this Commune; amongst the young soldiers was one who distinguished me by his attentions. At church he was ever by my side, and in our Sunday dances he was my constant partner. The preference of the handsome chasseur—for Hubert Malisset was then a good looking fellow—flattered my vanity—and in an evil hour, I consented to a private marriage with him.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Ah! I never had such luck.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
A short time, however, revealed to me his real character. I found he was a man without principle or honour,
of depraved heart, and dissolute habits. In a fit of intoxication he struck an officer of his regiment, for which he was tried by Court Martial, and sentenced to be shot. The night preceding the day on which his execution was to take place, he escaped from prison and fled into the mountains, when he joined a gang of contrabandista; soon after, according to the dying confession of an associate, he was killed in a conflict with the custom house officers on the frontier.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: A good riddance of such a fellow.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It would be false to say I regretted him; so when Maurice D'Arbel, a few years later, made me an offer of marriage I accepted him.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Just what I'd have done myself had I been in your place. Of course you thought no more of the wretch from whom heaven had delivered you!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Hush, Ninon, hush! that face I saw at the—those eyes which have thrice met mine of late—if Hubert Mallisset be living—that face—those eyes are his.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Good gracious—you frighten me. But I can't believe it, and I won't believe it. (Malisset shows his face at the window at back unperceived by the women) It's only a fancy of yours. An accidental likeness between some stranger and that honest man, who, thank heaven, can never trouble you more.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well, I'll try and banish it from my mind. (Malisset disappears) Hark! My little Claude is awake. (both rise) I must hasten to dress him.
sp.stage: (crosses to stairs, R., which she ascends)

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: And while you do so, I'll prepare breakfast.
sp.stage: (Marguerite ascends stairs, R., and enters room—Ninon laying the table, C., and singing—she takes a table cloth from table drawer, and spreads it, then takes jug and glasses, knives and plates, and bread from cupboard, L. 3 E.)

lg.l: The belle of our village was pretty Jannette,
Lira-lira-la-ra-lie;
Her lips were of coral—her eyes were of jet,
Lira-lara-la-ra-la-lie.
Lovers she had,
Good ones and bad;
For they all came courting to pretty Jannette;
Pretty Jannette, &c., &c., &c.,

sp.p: There, now I've only to fetch a jug of wine from the cellar, and all will be ready.
sp.stage: (takes a key from a nail in the wall near the fireplace, and a jug from the cupboard, then exit, R. U. E., singing)
Enter Victor Sanson and Hubert Malisset, from flat, C.— Sanson is dressed in the extravagant costume of a mountebank.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: Hey! What a charming little warbler? I wonder if she could be tempted to accept an engagement as the Algerine Nightingale in my Dramatic, Operatic, Cabalistic, and Calisthenic Troupe, who will have the honour to give their first performance before the nobility, gentry and respectable inhabitants of this celebrated—

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Bah! You never can leave off the showman's patter.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: Excuse me my dear friend. I flatter myself that nobody can sink the professional, and glide with greater ease into the elegant habits of private life, than the unfortunate, but still gentlemanly Marquis de Galochard.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Bravo Victor Sanson! You'll be believing yourself a real Marquis.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: Well, it's a pleasing delusion, and I indulge in it— there's a sort of glitter in a title, that dazzles the crowd.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Like the copper lace on your coat.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: If it did I should not be seen in your company. But don't let us quarrel about our respectability till we come to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: With all my heart. And now to business

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.stage: (taking conjuror's balls and cup from his pocket— sits at table and commences passing them)
sp.p: Right. Quite right! Nothing like business—one, two, three. Go on, don't mind me—there's no deception.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: You know when we accidentally met on the road to this village, you told me you had a commission to procure a healthy female infant.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: From eight to ten months old—as a substitute for the child of some Italian nobleman—whose name has been concealed from me.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Who cares for his name?

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: I understand that during the temporary derangement of the mother—caused by an alarm of fire in the chateau—her child died, and on her recovery, the doctor and her husband, fearing the effect which the loss might produce upon her mind, determined to practise a kind of fraud upon her.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: By imposing another kid upon her in place of the defunct.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: Your last three years in the galleys, Hubert, have given you a vulgarity of expression that I don't like. The doctor said it was the only means of preserving the lady's reason—perhaps her life. It is a case of humanity.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: And of a hundred livres, which the doctor has promised for the job, and of which I am to have half, provided I furnish you with a squaller of the requisite age and sex.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: That's understood! The noble incognito and the doctor will be outside that door at twelve o'clock to receive the child.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: And hand over the rhino. (pointing to cradle) There's the young 'un.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.stage: (crosses to L. C., looking at the Child)
sp.p: A sweet little thing, she'd make an angel on the tight rope. But, may there not be danger in the business—the nurse may have scruples.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: I'll answer for her. (Ninon sings without, R. 1 E.) Hush! I hear that girl coming back. You must get her out of the way—immediately—I'll keep out of view here.
sp.stage: (Malisset conceals himself behind the open door of the large cupboard, L.)

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.stage: R., carrying a jug of wine, singing.

lg.l: Lovers she had
Good ones and bad,
And they all came courting to pretty Jannette.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: The fame of the celestial beauty, which illumines this remote region, has attracted me.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: She don't understand poetry. I'll descend to the ordinary style. How? I am starring, my dear. You are remarkably pretty. (bows) The Marquis de Galochard assures you of the fact.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: The Marquis de—?

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: Galochard. A nobleman of immense landed property and innumerable castles in Spain, but who nevertheless employs his leisure hours contributing to the entertainment of the nobility, gentry, and respectable inhabitants of all the principal cities and towns in the world.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Oh! I'll lay a wager you're the manager of the Travelling Theatre, which opened this morning opposite the “White Horse.”

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p:
I have the honour to be the director of that magnificent Temple of Art. Permit me to offer you a season ticket for the first and positively the last performance of my troupe in this neighbourhood—being engaged under enormous penalties to appear on next Wednesday at St. Petersburg, before the Emperor of Austria, the Lord Mayor of London, and the other crowned heads of Europe. (trumpet and drum at
some distance) Here, the performance is going to commence. You'll be late for the exhibition of the gigantic Chinese Dwarf, and the wonderful Salamander of the Rocky Mountains.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: Oh, I would not miss the Salamander for anything.

sp.speaker: Sanson.
sp.p: Allow me to have the pleasure of conducting you to the Temple of Art. (trumpet and drum again) The public is becoming impatient for my appearance. The—

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.p: For a marquis, he has no pride.
sp.stage: Exeunt Sanson and Ninon, door in flat, C.
Marguerite then enters from her room, R., with Claude, whom she leads by the hand—they speak as they descend the stairs.

sp.speaker: Claude.
sp.p: To-morrow, then, papa will be home?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I trust he will, my child.

sp.speaker: Claude.
sp.p: Oh! I shall be so glad. (at the foot of the stairs) I'll tell you something, mama—I've been making a beautiful ship, (points to R.) just like papa's, only not quite so big, with masts, and sails, and ropes. Ninon made the sails for me, and its mast's finished. You'll be surprised when you see it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I have no doubt I shall.

sp.speaker: Claude.
sp.p: Oh! she's a beauty; and I've called her the Marguerite, after you, mama; and I'll go and fetch it.
sp.stage: Exit by door under the stairs, R.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Happy time of childhood—when the spirit knows no care, and the heart feels no sorrow.
sp.stage: Malisset comes from behind the door of the cupboard and stands, C.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.stage: (R., turns, sees Malisset, and starts back terrified)
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Marguerite!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It is no delusion then—you are—

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Hubert Malisset—your husband.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, no! for mercy's sake, say not so!

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: I should not mind a lie to oblige you; but the truth happens to suit my purpose better. You know I am your husband.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I do not! He was shot eight years ago in the mountains.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: True! but his wound was not mortal. A poor goatherd carried him to his hut; tended him for months, and cured him. On his recovery he became a traveller.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: A traveller!

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Well, a vagabond—if you like. In the course of his wanderings, he became acquainted with the interiors of most of the prisons of France, and made a rather long visit to the Director of the Galleys at Marseilles. This accomplished individual, I repeat, is your husband.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Wretch, do not approach me.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Oh, don't be afraid; I respect female delicacy. I know you've got a second husband, and a son, the boy who just now went into that room.
sp.stage: (he makes a movement towards the door, R.,—Marguerite, terrified, places herself before him)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Would you avenge yourself on an unoffending child?

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: What should I get by that? No—I have no wish to disturb your domestic tranquility; in an hour I shall have left this village, and you will never see me or hear of me again.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Will you, indeed, do this?

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: On one condition,—that you give me that child in the cradle.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Give you my little Neomi.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: She is not yours; and I have found an eligible position for her, in a noble family where she will be brought up with a silver ladle in her mouth. So you see, it's better you should let me have her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Never! Never! Her parents intrusted her to me, and with my life I will protect her.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Come, come; don't be a fool. The child I'll have.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You shall kill me first.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Kill you! You should not put that thought in my head. I may take the hint; but that is not all. Your son there will be in my power; he shall be my son—my pupil; I'll make him a vagabond—a robber—a convict—as I am.
sp.stage: (Marguerite sinks to the ground, fainting—a distant clock strikes twelve—a carriage is heard approaching—it passes the window outside from R. to L., and stops—the door is opened by Victor Sanson, who appears outside—the carriage is seen at the door—a Gentleman in the carriage —Victor Sanson makes a sign to Malisset, who takes the child out of the cradle, carries it to the door, back, and hands it to Victor Sanson, who is about to place it in the arms of the Gentleman—Malisset, alarmed by a faint cry from Marguerite, suddenly closes the door)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Stop! stop! help! (she rises and rushes to the window as the carriage passes) Help! robbers! help!

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Mad woman! The thing is done and can't be helped now.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It can, it shall. (pointing off through the window) See there, descending the hill, Neomi's mother, returning to claim her child. I will confess everything; the robbers shall be pursued, they cannot escape.

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: And your son.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah! Heaven pity me!

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Swear never to divulge the secret to any one. Come, there is no time to lose. Swear, or you know the consequence—your own death, and the ruin of your son.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh! Not for myself (kneels) but for you, my boy, to save you, my dear Claude. (to Malisset) I swear—

sp.speaker: Malis.
sp.p: Good! I leave you to meet your visitor. (going, but returns) But take heed, I shall be there, outside that window, observing you—not a word you utter can escape me; and if you attempt to betray me (aside) I have the means of silencing you.
sp.stage: Exit through door at back, L.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: He is gone, and I breathe again. What has happened? How shall I answer the unhappy mother when she asks for her child. (rises and goes to back; Miriam is seen C. to L.) Ah! she comes!—the terrible moment is at hand!
sp.stage: Enter Miriam hastily, door in flat, and comes down.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Marguerite, we are returned. (shakes Marguerite's hands) I was too impatient to wait for my husband, who is following me slowly down the hill. A low fever which he caught on his journey consumes his strength, and renders him unable to walk far on your rough roads. (taking off her cloak) I thought we should never arrive. My little angel!—how is she?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well—quite well.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Oh! I knew you would take good care, Martha. Is she asleep? Oh! I must kiss her!—but I'll make no noise. (moving towards the cradle, Marguerite stops her) You fear I may disturb her. Well, I can restrain my eagerness. Oh, Marguerite! our child is rich now!—the daughter of the poor fortune-teller of Marseilles will be the heiress of millions. That cradle which contains my treasure, would not, if filled with gold, hold her fortune. You will let me look at her as she sleeps. I'll step and breathe so soft as not to wake her.
sp.stage: (she goes to the cradle on tip-toe, holding her breath)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Poor mother!

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.stage: (drawing aside the curtains of the cradle)
sp.p: She is not here! Oh! you put her in your own bed—I will find her there.
sp.stage: (she ascends the stairs precipitately, and enters Marguerite's room, R.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: How will she support the blow! I will remove these things from her sight.
sp.stage: She collects the articles of the child's dress, which are scattered near the cradle; Miriam re-enters at the moment, and Marguerite conceals them under her cloak.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p:
She is not there. Where is she? Where is my child? (advancing to Marguerite) Ah!
you have her there, under your apron, hiding her from me. (she draws aside Marguerite's cloak, and snatches the child's clothes from her, and utters a piercing cry) Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No.
sp.stage: (Malisset appears outside the window watching during this scene)

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Why do you tremble then?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Because she is lost to you.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Not dead, yet lost to me! What is it you mean? Where is she? Let me see her instantly!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Alas! I cannot; she is gone.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Gone! Woman, woman! A mother stands before you demanding her child, and you answer with that cold marble face—“she is gone.” Beware!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Hate me—spurn me—kill me if you will. I can bear your fiercest anger without a murmur, you know not how I loved her.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: I do, I do! You could not have pressed my little darling to your bosom for six months without loving her; pity me for her sake, tell me where she is, who has taken her. Answer me, Marguerite, by a mother's love, by the love you bear your own Claude.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Cease to torture me. I cannot, I have taken an oath to be silent.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: What is your oath to me? (shaking her) My child. My Neomi! restore her to me, or I will wring the secret from your heart; or if gold will bribe you, you shall have enough to satisfy your utmost desires—bright crowns of pure gold. Unclipped crowns.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.stage: (L. C., covering her face with her hands, and turning away)
sp.p: Ah! Heaven forgive me!

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Barbarous woman! Cannot my misery touch your cold heart! (Reuben is seen to pass the window outside from R.) My husband!
sp.stage: The door at back opens, and Reuben enters—he appears feeble and supports himself by a staff.

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: My strength fails me. I feel that I have nearly reached the close of life's weary journey.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Reuben! Husband, come hither!
sp.stage: (she draws him eagerly down the stage)

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: Miriam! what has happened?

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Look—look on that woman.

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: Marguerite, is it not?

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Look at her—she has robbed us of our child. They have stolen our beloved.

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p:
Neomi! the child of my affection. Ah! (totters) This blow will kill me. (sinks into a chair) Oh! We are justly
punished for our ardent thirst of gold. Gold was the idol for which we toiled, and watched, and fasted. We worshipped it, we prayed for it, and we have gained it; but our child is lost. Miriam, Miriam, it is the hand of heaven, we must bend to chastisement.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Bend! no—I will rise up before heaven, and cry with a mother's voice, “Give me back my child!” (to Marguerite) Oh! accursed be the day I trusted her to a stranger! and thrice accursed thou who hast brought this woe upon us! May the day bring to thee no gladness and the night no peace. May shame and infamy pursue thee through life; and when thou diest may the bones of thy kindred shrink from thee in the grave!
sp.stage: (Marguerite apparently overwhelmed by Miriam's imprecations sinks gradually to the earth—Reuben has risen with sudden energy and approaches Marguerite)

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: She must tell what she has done with our child. Answer woman—I command you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Claude! Claude!

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I—I—dare not—my lips are sealed.

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: No answer—then die!
sp.stage: (he raises his staff to strike her a violent blow, Miriam arrests his arm, and Marguerite starts in terror to her feet)

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Hold! you must not kill her. Let me speak to her once more. I have been too harsh with her; she will yet yield to my prayers and pity me, for she is herself a mother. (throws herself on her knees before Marguerite, whose hand she clasps and kisses, while weeping) Marguerite, these are my tears that fall upon your hands. Oh! by those drops wrung from my breaking heart—tell me what has become of my child. By your hopes of heaven to which which we both look—by a mother's love, and a mother's agony, I implore you—tell me! You will—you will. (Marguerite seems deeply moved— Malisset outside the window—opens it quietly and listens intently) I feel your tears mingling with mine.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Heaven will pardon me and protect my boy! (to Miriam) Rise! you shall know all.
sp.stage: (Miriam rises, and Malisset, who has levelled his carbine at Marguerite, fires—she utters a piercing cry and falls into Miriam's arms —Malisset disappears)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh! he has kept his word.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Marguerite! She is dying!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You are avenged; I would tell you how Neomi, but—

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Oh! her eyes are fixed! Help! Reuben, call for help! she will die with the secret on her lips!
sp.stage: (Reuben goes off hastily by door at back, calling)

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.stage: (she places Marguerite in an arm chair, C.)
sp.p: Marguerite! Marguerite! Oh, for a minute's life longer! Ah! her lips move—she tries to speak—here—lay your head on my shoulder, and whisper in my ear.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Say you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: I do—but speak.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Where—where are they? Claude, Neomi!

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: Oh! (placing her hand on Marguerite's heart) She is dead!
sp.stage: Re-enter Reuben with Ninon and Villagers, door at back.

sp.speaker: Ninon.
sp.stage: (coming down hastily and looking at Marguerite)
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Reuben.
sp.stage: (drawing Marguerite's dress aside from her bosom, and points to a wound in her breast)
sp.p: Murdered!

sp.speaker: Miriam.
sp.p: And she carries her secret with her to the grave! But there is a power in a mother's love—to force—make the grave yield it up. I make a vow, from this hour, to devote myself to poverty, and will abandon all for the recovery of my child! Come, Reuben, take thy staff! We will go forth into the world's wilderness together—town by town, house by house, stone by stone we will seek, until we have found our beloved, our lost Neomi! Come, come!

div.stage: Reuben and Miriam go slowly up the stage—Claude enters from the “Rover,” R., with a child's ship in his hand; he calls joyously, “Look, mother!”—Ninon, by Marguerite's body makes a sign for him not to approach—one of the Villagers takes his hand—Sanson appears outside, looking through the window at back.

Scene.—An Open Space at the foot of the Bridge of Carignano, beyond which in the distance is seen the Harbour and Lighthouse, with vessels round the Mole. The bridge (which is practicable) is reached by steps from the stage, R., crossing obliquely to L. U. E., and conducts to road, L., winding up the Hill of Targona, at back. The hill is studded with villas and vineyards, and its summit is crowned by the Church of Santa Maria; a dilapidated house, L. , with a practicable door and window above; a street leading from the R. to the stage.

The curtain rises to lively dance music of a natural character. The place is crowded with people; Water Carriers; Vendors of lemonade, sherbet, ices, cakes, fruit, images, &c., passing to and fro; Fishermen mending their nets, others lying idly on the steps of the bridge, or playing music; a party of young Fishermen and Girls dancing to music of a piffern; Victor Sanson (now called Hector Fiaramonti), Hubert Malisett (now called Bravadura) and Spada enter, R., during the dance, and come down, R. The dance has now stopped.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I wish you had brought me by any other way than this. There are certain institutions I have a decided objection to. That black prison we passed just now (points off, R.) gave me a cold shiver.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: (R.) Yet it is the handsomest in Genoa.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: The finest in all Italy—I know every one of them perfectly, inside and out.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Your opportunities for the study of these public edifices have been greater than mine, but I cannot look at one of them without a depression of spirits.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Then, look at yonder house and let your spirits rise again. (pointing to Rudiga's house, L.) Our fortune lies there!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Where? In that tumble-down ruin?

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: A ruin that will pay us better than a palace. A rough nut with a sweet kernel. Don't you know 'tis the house of Rudiga, the Jewess.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: A strange terrible woman! Years ago I met her in Leghorn, where she was called the Sorceress. Afterwards I saw her at Naples, where she got the name of the Card Drawer.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: I knew her at Rome, and Bologna, and Milan, as the Magician and the Sybil.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Here in Genoa they call her “The Woman in Red.” She apparently lives by fortune-telling—but that's only a cloak. She has a better trade than that.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hey! Two strings to the devil's bow! What is the second?

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Money lending.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Bah! what has a poor wretch like that to lend?

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Some of our beggarly nobles and struggling merchants could tell you, During the past year she has lent two hundred thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Two hundred—thousand!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: An hundred thousand to the Dorias; fifty thousand to the brothers Capirani; thirty thousand to Fosco, and twenty thousand to Guistiniani—all in hard gold.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: And I was simple enough to think she wasn't worth a ducat—body and soul. You're sure you're right, though?

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Right! Was Bravadura's nose ever wrong where there was a scent of plunder? But to-night we will convince ourselves.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: To-night—(half showing his dagger) I'll be ready.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Let's have no blood-letting, I don't like it—it's vulgar.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Pooh! you were always squeamish, marquis.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Don't call me marquis any more; you know I abandoned my title when we were forced to quit France sixteen years ago—on account of that unfortunate affair at Marguerite D'Arbel's cottage.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Why will you always keep reminding me of that day?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Because I can never forget it was a bad business.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Then why did you join me in it? You had your fair share of the money—fifty Louis.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Yes, and I'd give fifty times the sum—if I had it— that I'd never had anything to do with it; it was enough to kidnap the child, but the murder of the woman—

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: That was my affair; a chicken-hearted fellow like you would have heard Marguerite D'Arbel confess the secret that would have brought us both to the galleys; the words were on her lips when a bullet from my arquebus stopped them.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Poor Marguerite. I'm glad that deed does not lie on my conscience.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, ha!—it makes me laugh to hear a fellow without a ducat in his pocket talking of
       his conscience, 
 but take care that your conscience keeps its mouth shut;
       Diavolo, if I thought you'd leak, I'd make sure of you.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: There, don't! You've a ugly habit of handling that bit of steel there. I don't mean to leak, my dear rascal. (crosses, L.—aside) When we eat macaroni with the devil, we must take care we don't burn our fingers.
sp.stage: Music at a distance—Caterina comes down the bridge from L., running round the stage laughing, and comes down, R.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Let us change the subject. There's some merriment going forward to-day. I'll ask that black-eyed little rogue what it means. (crosses to L., and bows to Caterina) Charming Donzella, what is the cause of these rejoicings.

sp.speaker: Caterina.
sp.p: Don't you know that the wife of Matte Twitti, the bird-catcher, has brought him another son, and all the neighbours have been to the christening. Matte is chirping like one of his own birds with delight.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Happy Matte! I must offer him my congratulations.

sp.speaker: Cater.
sp.p: Here they come!—here they come!
sp.stage: Matte and Ninetta, followed by a Nurse carrying the Infant, with Theresa, Marcella and Maria, form a little procession which comes from L. to C. and enter; the People cheer as Matte and Ninetta come down; Matte has tame birds perched on his head and shoulders, and he carries a cage full of birds in his hand.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Friends and neighbours, I accept your congratulations with pride and pleasure. I thank you. (bows) My wife thanks you. (Ninetta curtseys) My pretty little birds thank you. (the birds begin to sing) And the interesting young stranger, whom I have the honour to present to you, (points to child, and shows it) would thank you if he was able.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Matte. You are making a fool of yourself.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: My angel, I never made a fool of myself but once, and that was when I was going to drown myself, because you refused to marry me, but I trapped you at last. Ha, ha, caught you, and kept you ever since.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Permit me to compliment you upon your good fortune, in having secured so charming a companion, for the domestic cage.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Oh sir! (starts and aside) Surely I have seen that face before.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Yes; I'm the happiest fellow in Genoa, with my wife, my children, and my birds. (birds sing) There, that's music!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Which music do you mean?
sp.stage: (Ninetta snatches the child from Matte, and sings to it while rocking it in her arms; the child crying, and the birds singing all the while)

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Both Sir—all—That's a family concert you don't hear every day.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: No—thank heaven!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Ninetta and I have been married six years. We have got a comfortable little home, a brisk trade in singing birds and sweetmeats, and a thriving family of five boys— there they are—bless their dear little hearts.
sp.stage: (kisses them one after the other, finishing up with the baby and Ninetta)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Five sons in six years.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Yes, sir, and if I live to have fifty, I'll make bird catchers of them all. (People laugh) And why not? What life so merry and so free, as a bird-catcher's?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Aye, aye!

sp.speaker: Matte.

lg.l: When morning opens her eyes,
Before the early lark I rise,
And then with bird-call, sweet and clear,
I roam the country far and near.
The pretty warblers know the sound,
And every bird comes flocking round,
The young and old—the wild and shy,
A merry bird-catcher am I.
Oh, could I but invent a snare,
To take the lasses young and fair,
I'd catch them all, and happy be,
For every lass, should sing for me.
.—Whistling, singing, blythe and gay
Kissing, chirping, all the day,
Pretty Twitti—how they'd cry—
A merry bird-catcher am I.

sp.stage: Enter the Countess Constanza Donati, R., veiled—she looks round cautiously and addresses Theresa.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray, which is the house of Rudiga, the fortune-teller?

sp.speaker: Theresa.
sp.p: The Woman in Red—she lives there. (points, L.) You have business with her, perhaps—something you have lost.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Something I would find.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: A lover, or a lost dog?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Thus closely veiled, nobody can know the Countess Donati, whose last hope of saving the credit of her
husband lies in this woman.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: What do you want with the sorceress, Marcella?

sp.speaker: Marcel.
sp.p: Only to ask about my husband, who has been away nine months on a voyage. If the fortune-teller read in the cards that I am a bereaved widow—

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: You'll have to marry again.

sp.speaker: Marcel.
sp.p: I fear that must be my sad fate.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: They say she foretells the most extraordinary things. She predicted only a month ago, that Pietro Costara would soon rise to an elevated position, and he was hanged last Thursday.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Bah! any one could have told you that! This woman takes your money, and laughs at you.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: No, no! she gets no money from me; and yet she told me I should ride in a carriage some day.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: A carriage provided by the state, when you ride some fine morning to the gallows, Spada.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: Oh! I'm in no hurry for such an honour. I can wait.

sp.speaker: Marcel.
sp.p: She won't answer.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: She may not be at home. I will come again this evening, after vespers.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: If there was any chance of getting to that window, one might look in.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: A good idea. Here, you ladder-backed scarecrow, stand still! (to Spada, who is endeavouring to peep through a crevice in the door—he mounts on his back, and looks in at the window) It's the way of the world: one man mounts to fortune on another man's shoulders.
sp.stage: (while he looks through the window, Rudiga suddenly opens the door—Spada retreats in alarm, and lets Matte fall to the ground—the Crowd, who had approached near the house, retire precipitately—Rudiga, apparently absorbed in thought, advances to C.)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Sixteen years!—sixteen weary years of fruitless search!

sp.speaker: Marcel.
sp.p: Speak to her—you.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: What can she be muttering to herself!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Some cabalistic spell, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Bah! she's calculating the interest on her last loan.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: I want you to tell me my fortune. You can read the book of fate in my hand as well as in the cards. Just look at mine. Have I the lines of long life and riches; and (lowering her voice) Will Matte be always a good husband?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ha! I remember her face and voice! (to Ninetta) Your hand. (she looks at Ninetta's hand) You have children, and you will be happy. The tree without fruit is accursed!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Little bird-catchers, my good woman—all chirping and lively. Could you oblige us by telling us if we shall make up the dozen?
sp.stage: (Rudiga regards him haughtily, and waves away the people who have crowded round her)

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: Back! back all! I have to speak to her alone. (the people retire submissively—she changes her tone in addressing Ninetta—crosses to R.) Ninon.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Hah! It is a long time since I was called Ninon, not since I was a girl, in my native village, where I married Matte Twitti, and came to live with him here in Genoa. They now call me Ninetta. But who are you?

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: Look in my face. Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: No, no; your features are strange to me.

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: Alas! sixteen years of misery have changed me. The first and last time we met was in the cottage of the unfortunate Marguerite D'Arbel.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Oh! I recognize you now. You are Miriam the Jewess, whose child disappeared on that terrible day. Have you recovered her since?

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: No, no. Heaven in its anger still withholds her from me.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: And your husband—where is he?

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: Poor Reuben sleeps with his fathers; the loss of our infant killed him; but I lived, for the mother's heart could not rest even in the grave, until it had felt once more the pressure of the child she had borne in her bosom. In every town and city of Europe I have sought my Neomi. Despised, insulted, wherever I came—the poor Jewess had but one thought in her heart—one prayer on her lips. “My child! My child! Oh, God of Israel, give me back my child!”

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Poor mother! poor mother! And you still cling to the hope of finding her.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Hope sustains me, for I hold a double power in my hands—superstition and gold. These are my master keys, with which I can unlock the secrets of every heart. (the People murmur—aside) These people grow impatient for me. (to Ninetta). In! (addressing the People) Come all—the dark pages of destiny are opened to my view—approach and listen.
sp.stage: (she spreads her large red cloak on the ground at the foot of the bridge, kneels on one knee, and arranges the cards on her cloak—the People crowd round and watch her with eager interest—while thus engaged)
Enter Count Claudio, R. to L. C.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hah! the young Count Claudio—the very man I want to have a little private conversation with. (approaches Claudio and takes off his hat) Your most obedient, count—one word with you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: This, if I mistake not, is the third time you have accosted me.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Precisely—the third time in three years; and if you remember the first time, I warned you of a danger.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Which I avoided.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: The second time, of an enemy's plot.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Which, thanks to your information, I defeated,

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: This time, I have to put you on your guard against a snare into which you are walking unconsciously.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What snare?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: The most dangerous to our weak sex—that which a woman spreads.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I cannot read your meaning.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Need I ask why the gallant Count Claudio comes every morning through the narrow streets of this quarter, and takes his stand at the foot of this bridge—if it be not to meet a certain fair young signora returning from devotions in the chapel of Santa Maria de—

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Francisca Donati.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Ha! Have I hit the mark? The signora is young and beautiful—you believe also that she is rich.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Her father is amongst the wealthiest merchants in Genoa.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: A mistake! Paulo Donati has invested large sums in some hazardous speculations with the house of Juan Rebollado, in Barcelona. These speculations have failed. Rebollado is on the verge of bankruptcy, and Donati will be ruined. A friend just arrived from Barcelona, where Donati is now striving to sustain the tottering firm, has brought me this news,—'tis every word true. If you marry Francisca Donati, you will be duped. Take the warning as you like— I give it you as a friend.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What claim can I have upon your friendship?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: You are the son of Marguerite D'Arbel who was assassinated sixteen years ago.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Oh! you knew my mother?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I can't say I did; but I happened accidentally to be a witness of the fact. I saw you then, a brave little fellow, standing beside the body of your murdered parent, and I made a promise to myself that I would be your friend and protector should you ever need my help.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I thank you with all my heart; and the more so that your voluntary guardianship appears to be perfectly disinterested.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Well, the fact is, I took a fancy to you. I'm a strange sort of fellow; good or bad as the wind blows, and if the gallows don't prevent my pious instructions I shall die a saint at four-score.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And you assure me that Francisca's father is ruined?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Ruined; unless he can produce fifty thousand crowns to meet his engagement next month. I should not like to see the wealth your rich uncle bequeathed to you swallowed up in the gulf into which Paul Donati's fortunes are sinking.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I care not, I will never forsake Francisca—my fortune will suffice for both; still I thank you, friend, for your caution.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Oh, don't mention it; follow your own inclination, marry the girl if you like—perhaps I admire you the more for it—I have been myself a martyr to the tender passion. Adieu, Count; I perceive the beauteous object of your affections descending the hill.
sp.stage: (Francisca appears descending the steep path from the church of Santa Maria, at back, L., and crosses the bridge from L. to R.)

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Ah! the Signora Francisca Donati—she always stops to ask after my children.

sp.speaker: Cater.
sp.p: Oh, she's a kind and beautiful young lady, and so charitable.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Not the least pride about her.

sp.speaker: Cater.
sp.p: Everybody loves her.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: What a beautiful little foot!

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: What a superb gold chain!
sp.stage: (Francisca comes down, C.—the Men take off their hats— the Women curtsey—Claudio meets her, kisses her hand, addresses her apart, and leads her down, C.)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I fear I have kept you waiting, Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No—no!—take my arm, and let us get out of this crowd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: One moment, I must not forget my little pensioners
sp.stage: (the Children crowd around her—she distributes money among them—murmurs, and gestures of admiration amongst the crowd)

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Sweet angel! shall I ever be worthy of her?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Noble young lady; would you learn your fortune from the cards? I am Rudiga, the daughter of the stars—the handmaid of destiny. I can trace the line of fate in your hand, or read the fortune in your face.
sp.stage:
(looks attentively in Francisca's face,
suddenly starts back—aside)
sp.p: Hah! the features of our race— the living image of Reuben, as he looked when first I loved him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Take my hand, Francisca?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She would have been just her age.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How that strange woman looks at me! Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: They call her the Woman in Red.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A stranger?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: A Jewess?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A Jewess!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A Jewess! Oh!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She, too, abhors our race. If she had been my child, the blood of Isaac and of Jacob would not have shrunk from its source.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: See—she weeps!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Neomi—my loved and lost one!
sp.stage: (Rudiga seats herself on the steps of her own door)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Unhappy woman! She seems crushed by grief and misery! I am sorry now I let her perceive my repugnance to her nation. Jewess or not, she is poor and wretched! (offering her purse to Rudiga) Here!— take this!

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: Keep your money!—I need it not!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You are proud!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Why should I not be proud? Am I not the daughter of an ancient, glorious race!—the chosen of the earth!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Offers made in kindness deserve not to be rejected with scorn.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Her voice!—'tis the echo of my own, as I remember it long ago! Speak, lady!—speak again, in mercy!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come—come, Claudio, she terrifies me!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Stop one moment.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: My Neomi had a mark on her shoulder—a seal imprinted on her snowy skin—by nature's hand, if it be there—'tis she.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Insolent woman, why do you stop our path—away, or (points to R. off) the prison is at hand.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Speak gently to her, Claudio.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Let us leave her—she must be mad.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p:
Aye, that is what they say— “she is mad.” For this I have been hunted like a wild beast, driven with curses from every door, cast into dungeons,
chained, whipped, tortured. Oh! I cried to men for pity— but there was no pity for me on earth, then I raised voice to Heaven—but Heaven was deaf to my prayers.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What is it you want? Why are you a wanderer on earth?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: A sacred instinct, a hope that my heart tells me, will one day be realised—leads me on my path alone through the world.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alone! Ah! How sad your fate.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You pity me. Yes, your eyes are bent in tenderness upon me—a light breaks upon the darkness of sixteen years in my soul, a power which I cannot resist, draws me to you—let me but kiss that cheek, and press your head upon my aching heart. (Francisca shrinks back) Deny me not. (drops on her knees) I am not proud now—see I am on my knees before you, in the dust, I ask but one embrace, once to fold you in my arms.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: A Christian maiden's cheek shall not be sullied by the lips of a Jewess.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No no!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Forbid her not. Heaven yields to Christian and to Jew his equal mercy. The sun that warms to life, the blessed rain, and gentle dew, the sky, the sea, the earth, all nature's countless blessings—do they not flow from the same bounteous hand, alike on Jew and Gentile. It is not much I ask.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: It must not be. Come Francisca.
sp.stage: (drawing Francisca away, crosses R., and goes up, L.)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: No, no! (aside) My life hangs on this moment. I must be convinced or die.
sp.stage: (attempting to hold Francisca while Claudio draws her away)

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Off, wretch, off!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Spurn me! kill me! still I will cling to her.
sp.stage: (Claudio separates them and draws Francisca—Rudiga following her on her knees and endeavouring to grasp her dress, in doing so, she accidentally seizes a gold cross which Francisca wears suspended from her neck—the cross remains in Rudiga's hands)

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: She has snatched the cross from your neck. (to the People) See, this wretched Jewess has profaned the emblem of our faith. She has stolen the sacred Cross from the bosom of a Christian maid.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, no—it was accident.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: Hah! sacrilege! sacrilege!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Down with the Jewess! down with the Jewess!

sp.speaker: Others.
sp.p: Down with the Jewess! Death to the Sorceress! Haah!—hooh!—Aa-h!
sp.stage: (the People rush around Rudiga, who goes towards the bridge, where she is met by two Peasants)

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Over the bridge with her!

sp.speaker: Others.
sp.p: Aye, aye! over the bridge! Hurrah!
sp.stage: (the Mob draws her towards the bridge—Claudio endeavours to force Francisca away—she breaks from him and runs towards Rudiga)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stop—I command! (the Mob involuntarily obey her) If you execute your barbarous design, you must kill me.
sp.stage: (she rushes to Rudiga, who hastily draws Francisca's dress from her breast, and discovers the mark by which she identifies her as her lost child—she utters a piercing cry, and clasps Francisca to her bosam)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Neomi!

div.stage: (Claudio and the Crowd surround them, with expressions of surprise and pity as the Act drop descends)

Scene First.—Rudiga's House; a large dilapidated apartment with vaulted roof; a small chamber or alcove, on the left of a massive stone pillar C. flat, from which the roof springs; a poor pallet is seen within the alcove; a massive door with heavy locks and fastenings to right of pillar, flat; a window with broken glass, R. 2 E.; a door covered with tattered tapestry, R. flat; another door, L.; a large table, R. C., covered with an old cloth of various colours, on which is placed a skull, an hour glass; a few old books, packs of cards, and an iron lamp of antique form; a skeleton hangs on the pillar at back, and a large box studded with brass nails stands near the alcove, L.)
Rudiga is discovered seated R. of table; her elbow resting on the table, and her head on her hand as in profound thought.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Yes, yes; it was she; that mark upon her breast convinced me. It was my Neomi. The treasure I have sought for sixteen years is found, but found in the possession of another.
sp.stage:
(she buries her face in her hands and weeps—a continued noise as of filing and rapping has been heard from the commencement of the Scene at window, R.—the window at length opens, and Bravadura, Hector,
and Spada enter masked, unperceived by Rudiga, who seems to rouse herself from her despondency)
sp.p: I will weep no more. Tears are for the weak. The courage which has sustained me for so many years must not fail me now.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Your keys!

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: Your gold!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: If it be not putting you to too much trouble, madame.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Who speak? Ah! masked men! robbers!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Tax collectors, madame; gentlemen whose exchequers require to be replenished as well as the duke's.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: And you expect to supply your wants in this miserable place?

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: No words; come to business, or—

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Your keys, this instant!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Take them.
sp.stage: (she detaches her keys from her girdle, and throws them on the table—they each take a key and unlock various cupboards and boxes, and search about everywhere)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Excuse our impertinent curiosity, but your house is so full of interest, that we must have a peep into every corner,

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: What have you got there?

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Rags and rubbish. Have you found anything?

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: Yes. Old pans and dishes—nothing else.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Nothing, my friends, absolutely nothing.

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: A rotten nut not worth the cracking.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! I expected you, and was prepared for you. You seek for gold—there it is for you?
sp.stage: (she takes a handful of gold pieces out of the skull and flings them on the ground—Bravadura and Spada scramble for the gold, Hector looks at them)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Why do you not scramble for your share?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Because 'tis not worth the trouble. Let them have it: I take what fortune sends me on easier terms.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ah! you are not a common robber?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Oh dear no! The art of extracting gold is a science—a species of alchemy, which requires skill and delicacy. (apart to her) A few pieces will satisfy these poor devils; but with my expensive tastes and extravagant habits I really must have the means, and when I meet a liberal friend—

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I understand—you want money. One word. Will you serve me?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Serve you? Will you trust me?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Let me look at your face.
sp.stage: (she snatches off his mask—Bravadura and Spada rush upon her with their daggers)

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: We are discovered!

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: If my face was as ugly as yours, I might be ashamed to have it seen. You shall not harm her!

sp.speaker: Spada.
sp.p: Ugh!—he's a fool!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Let us begone.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Go; I'll follow you directly.
sp.stage: Bravadura and Spada open door, R. 3 E., and exit.
sp.p: You know me?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I do; your name is Victor Sanson.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: The devil! How did you discover that?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You forgot I am a magician. The cards reveal everything to me. (she takes a pack of cards from the table and looks through them) They tell me that on the 16th of July, 1670, you were exhibiting with a troupe of strolling comedians in the village of Castellan, on the French side of the Alps.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: True! Have the cards told you that!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: More still. You were arrested on suspicion of having murdered Marguerite D'Arbel.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I was innocent, though, of that crime; the cards will tell you so.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: They do.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: That 16th July was an unlucky day for me?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It was the dark day of my existence; for on that day, my child, whom I had entrusted to Marguerite D'Arbel, was stolen.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Was that beautiful infant yours?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: He saw her, then! (eagerly) Yes, yes! and you—you know who it was that stole her!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: The cards show it! There—you dare not deny it!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I—I don't deny it! I admit I was acquainted with the kidnapper of the sweet little creature.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ah! you can tell, then, what has become of her!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I wish I could; but it's impossible. I am in utter ignorance of her fate.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Alas! (sinks into a chair) There can be no proof then by which I can make good my claim against this powerful family. (weeps) May the cruel hands that robbed me of my child—

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p:
Stop—stop—don't curse them; it's not pleasant, though you have had cause for it. I'm a vagabond—worthless
fellow—the companion of rogues and vagabonds. I have gambolled, robbed, and cheated, but amongst all crimes the only one which eats at my heart like a remorse is the recollection of—

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: No matter—what's past is past, and can't be helped, I can't tell how it is, but the sight of your tears melt me. (with emotion) I'm not naturally bad, and when I think what I might—what I was—what I am—I—I—hang it! I'll not make a fool of myself. Take my hand—command me—I am your slave.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You will obey me?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hector Fiaramonte—I mean Victor Sanson—gives you his hand upon it.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Hear me then. I have discovered my long-lost child.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hah! I give you joy.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Yes, I have found my daughter, but still she is not mine.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Your daughter who is not your daughter! If this be the language of the cards, 'tis by no means intelligible.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She lives—I have seen her—heard her—clasped her in these arms, but I dared not say I was her mother. She has been brought up as the daughter of a rich family in this city.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Well, why don't you claim her?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Alas! who would listen to me—who would believe that the noblest and fairest maid in Genoa could be the offspring of the despised Jewess?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: True, the prejudices of the world are disgusting. I've been their victim all my life. (sighs) What do you mean to do then?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I will tell you. My child was stolen from me in infancy, why should I not recover her by the same means?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I don't see why you should not.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: A thousand ducats shall be yours, if you will aid me.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I understand. (aside) Kidnap her daughter a second time. (crosses, L.) Well, I have helped to carry off girls before now, for parties who were not their mothers. I take your offer, a thousand ducats. I'll have your daughter for you—if she was shut in a fortress. By the bye; you must tell me the name she is now known by.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Francisca Donati!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Francisca Donati. The betrothed of Count Claudio?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: You would not separate them?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I would—I must. Neomi shall never be the wife of him whose mother died with that terrible secret in her heart which made me a childless wanderer for so many years.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: But your daughter loves him.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I hate him, that is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: To recover your daughter, my life is at your service, provided that no harm comes to Count Claudio; a hair of his head shall not be hurt.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I said a thousand ducats—I will make it five thousand.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Five thousand! I am not master of ten scudi in the world, but still I have strength to say “No.” I was always fond of expensive luxuries, and now throw away five thousand ducats for the gratification of feeling that I have still a heart. (going) Adieu, madame.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Take this purse with you.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Excuse me, I have not earned your money— another time perhaps. Adieu! make my respects to the Goddess Fortune, though she has proved but a hard stepmother to me, adieu.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: My fate! my fate! Even gold cannot tempt this reckless fellow to my purpose. Is it that heaven is angry with me, and will not hear my prayers? Has my child been clasped in my arms for a moment, only to make my agony more bitter? (sinks on the floor) Will she ever be mine—all mine? Will Heaven ever pity my despair! (prostrating herself, her hands come in contact with the cards which the robbers have thrown on the floor) The cards, the cards, they have told truth sometimes, every mystery is not a juggle. (gathering the cards) They told me I should see my child—I have seen her. (she disposes the cards in order on the floor) What do they say now? A strange woman always stands between me and my Neomi, she is still there—like death. Neomi turns towards the strange woman, and away from me— her mother. Lies! lies! the cards lie. Yet I'll try once more. (she again spreads out the cards) Ah! What is this? The first person who enters my door, will restore me my daughter. Ah, ah! how my hands tremble, and my heart beats—who is this person? Ah! (the door L. flat opens and Constanza Donati appears at it—she is enveloped in a cloak, and wears a close veil—Rudiga turns quickly) Who is there? (apart) A woman! ah!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Perhaps I disturb you.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: No—you may enter. (aside) Veiled. (aloud) You come to consult me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes. (comes down R.) You are a magicienne.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Magicienne, sorceress, diviner by cards. My soul communicates with the past, and penetrates the future. Your hand.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: There is high blood in these veins. Lift your veil.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What need I? You should know me by the art you practise, without seeing my face.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Hah! I see the arms of Donati enamelled on the back of the watch she wears. (aloud) You are Constanza Donati.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am. (raising her veil) How did you discover me?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: The cards tell me all; sit down. (points to a seat on R. of table—Constanza sits—aside) This is the woman that stands between me and my child.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Her looks make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: By which method shall we read the book of fate?—the magic pack, of thirty-two cards, (points to one pack of cards) or the Great Eteitta of seventy-eight cards here.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: By that.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You know me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Only by report. They call you Rudiga, the fortune-teller —the Woman in Red.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: And Rudiga the Jewess—Rudiga the money-lender and usurer.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, sometimes.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I am known by many names. (cuts the cards into three packs) These three packs represent what fate sends. To yourself—to your house—to your wishes. Now select one for the first. (Constanza points to one of the packs—Rudiga takes it, and spreads the cards in order on the table) You have travelled much, with a female child, who has caused you great uneasiness.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Go on!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Wherever you went you were pursued by a constant fear which haunted you like a spectre; you dreaded that the child would be taken from you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My darling Francisca was in delicate health.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Had you no apprehension but for her health? Was the hand of death the only one that you feared might be stretched to snatch her from you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Whose else should I fear? (aside) Can this woman know?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Let us pass that. Choose for “your house” now. (Constanza points to a pack—Rudiga examining the cards) Black! black! Do you fear to be told the truth?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I came to hear it.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You are threatened with misfortune—ruin. Hah! a faced card—see, the Queen of Spades; it brings grief and mourning under your roof.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Death, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: No. A life-long separation. Hah! your daughter— (examining the cards) It is strange!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Strange—most strange!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What do you see? Speak—tell me—tell me!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Your daughter. (impressively) She is not your daughter.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Insolent woman! How dare you utter such a falsehood!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: The cards are never false. They have said it— you are not her mother.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am—I am! She is mine!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Yours? You are a high-born woman—patrician blood flows in your veins! that girl whom you call your daughter is of plebeian birth—the offspring of an accursed and banished race.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You are a Christian, she is a Jewess!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You shall wound my ears no longer by your base inventions. I will not listen another moment to your lies!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Hold! Shall I lie if I tell you what brought you to this miserable door to-night?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I do not wish to hear.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: But you shall! It was not the fortune-teller you sought so much as the money-lender.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: The rich Jewess, whose secret hoards may sustain the tottering fortune of the merchant prince, your husband.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: It was (comes down) to—to—

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Paulo Donati writes from Barcelona, imploring you to raise amongst your friends a loan of fifty thousand ducats, which he must have within ten days, or become a bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You know all, then?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Your friends have proved a broken reed. They will not lend you a ducat; and, as a last resource, you come to me. Well, (opening a secret recess in the pillar, C., in which is seen a casket, bags and heaps of coin, vessels of gold and silver, and other riches) Look there! There's treasure enough to buy a city!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Ah! you have the power to save us! Fifty thousand ducats would enable my husband to meet his engagements and maintain his credit. The money will be
repaid to you, and for security I have still my dower—my settlement—which I am prepared to mortgage for the debt. Here is the deed prepared. (gives paper to Rudiga) You can save my husband's honour and his life; for he will never survive the loss of his honour.

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: It will not do.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My diamonds, then—my jewels! I will place them in your hands; only save us from ruin!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: They are not sufficient.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What would you have then from me?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: One word—one single word of truth. Is Francisca your child?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What does it concern you to know?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Answer my question, or you get no gold from me. Is she your daughter?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You have no right to question me.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I wish to prove the truth of my science—think of your husband. (takes the casket from the recess, and places it on the table) There is twice the sum you want in the casket— speak, and it is yours.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why does she try to wring my secret from me? (to R.) I will come to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: To-morrow will be too late—to-night, it must be or—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Stay—a minute. (to Rudiga) If I confess—shall I lose, Francisca?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ah! she is not your child!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Hush! You have surprised my secret—but knowing so much, you shall know all. More than sixteen years ago a sudden stroke deprived me of reason, and for several months I lived in a mental darkness. During this period my infant daughter died, and when my reason returned, she, whom I believed to be my own, was nestling in my bosom.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: But you discovered afterwards that she was not your child.

sp.speaker: Const.
Rudig.
sp.p: And you cared not for the agony of the mother from whom she had been torn.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Every feeling was absorbed in my love for the dear child. But, perhaps you know her mother?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.stage: Yes! I know her—she is called Rudiga the Jewess! I am her mother!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Aye—can you not read the mother's joy in my face? Ah! my long years of misery are forgotten like a dream. (pushing the casket towards Constanza) Here, take what you will—it is yours—all is too little for the blessing that has fallen on me—I am too rich, now that I have found my child.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No—keep it—I will not touch it. I can seek help elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: But you will restore me my daughter, will you not?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ah! take care!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Never—never!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I will appeal to justice. You have confessed she is not your child!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I will deny it.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Your conscience will not let you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I can be silent.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You shall be compelled to speak. Dare you perjure yourself!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You know not what I would dare.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Then you shall not leave this room.
sp.stage: (places herself between Constanza and the door)

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ah, detained by force. Open the door and let me pass, or I will have you whipped through the city.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! you forgot that 'tis I who command here. Sit down, Constanza Donati, and write me an order for Francisca to go with me, her mother—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Are you mad!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Write!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I must dispense with your authority then, and use my own.
sp.stage: (she takes her mantle and puts it on)

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: To my daughter.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No; you shall not go near her, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Back! back! here you remain.
sp.stage: (Rudiga exits hastly, door, R. C., flat, shuts the door, and is heard to lock it outside)

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Woman!—mercy!—come back! (beats the door violently with her hands) Help! Ah, Francisca, help! Some one—help—my child! Ah!

div.stage: (sinks exhausted on the floor— closes in)
Scene Second. —A Street in Genoa; Night.
Enter Matte Twitte, R., slightly intoxicated, and singing the refrain of the Bird-Catcher's song.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Yo-yo-yo-yo-yo-oo-oo ic tooi-tooi-tooi—ha, ha, ha' ha! That last bottle has set me chirping like one of my own canaries, tweet, tweet, tweet, too, too, tweet. Well, when a man has been six times a mother—I mean, when a woman has been six times a father—no, no, when a mother has been a father—no, I should say, when a father has been a mother six times, he ought to be congratulated accordingly; I've been congratulating myself, and drinking to the health of the little stranger who has recently made his appearance in the domestic nest; I wish I was comfortably there too, but the streets wind in such an extraordinary manner that a sober man is all night getting home; Government must look to it—Government must really look to it. Now there will be my dear little wife sitting up for me—and I know she will not be in the sweetest of tempers; she'll say I've been getting drunk, which is abom— abom-'able; and very likely she'll say I've been gallanting, ha, ha, ha, ha!—gallanting—ha, ha, ha, ha! as if I was capable of anything of the sort—ah! it's a dreadful calamity for a man to have a jealous wife; what a life she leads me about Pippa, the pretty sempstress who lives opposite our house—well, if Pippa has the brighest and blackest eyes in the world she can't help it, and if I sometimes look across the street to admire those eyes I can't help it; but, good gracious, if Ninetta were to catch me at it wouldn't there be warm work for the ears.
sp.stage: Enter Constanza Donati, veiled, precipitately, L.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I will ask the stranger to protect me. (she lays her hand on Matte's arm) My good friend. (Matte starts away) You need not fear me—I am a defenceless woman!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: A woman! Don't come nearer, I don't wish it, I have my reasons for it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But I am unprotected.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am in danger.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am endeavouring to reach my home.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh! my strength fails, ah! support me.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: I can scarcely support myself.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: For heaven's sake let us not remain here. Come, come!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Bless me, how you tremble. (aside) I can't see her face, but this rich silk mantle isn't the plumage of a vulgar bird.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If you will accompany me to the Palazzo Donati, you shall be well rewarded for your trouble.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: The Palazzo Donati! I feel myself getting rapidly sober. Certainly Signora, certainly—don't be afraid to lean on me.

sp.speaker: Ninetta.
sp.p: It's always the case, when Matte goes out without me, he falls into what he calls pleasant company; as if a man's wife wasn't pleasant company for him. I know he has been spending the night at the wine shop, and he'll be coming home alone, so I thought I'd meet him, and take care of him— he's such a fool is Matte.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: It's my wife.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: This is the way he should come. (sees Matte and Constanza) Ah! what? Matte—my husband!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: You're right, my dear!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Matte—with a woman!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Right again, my angel.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: What, you are not ashamed to confess your baseness? Who is this creature? Let me see her face. Ah, you do well to conceal it under a veil.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Hush! Ninetta—hush—she is—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: The Signora Donati. (Ninetta retires abashed and surprised) Escaping from a house where I had been made prisoner, I met your husband, and placed myself under his protection.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Oh! Signora—I beg pardon—I—I thought—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Never mind explanations; but hasten home with me, for I fear the shadow of an enemy may have fallen on my threshold before I can cross it.

div.stage: Exit Constanza, Matte and Ninetta, R.
Scene Third — An Apartment in the Donati Palace; richly furnished; at back an open window with balcony, overlooking a street in Genoa; doors R. and L.; a table R. on which stands a lighted lamp.
Maria standing at balcony, Claudio enters L. C., Maria comes down to meet him.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Any tidings yet, Signor—of my lady?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No, I have been to the houses of all her friends, where she might possibly have been detained, but have obtained no intelligence of her.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: What will become of my poor young mistress?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Dear Francisca! this strange disappearance of her mother must alarm her terribly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Maria!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: She calls you, Maria. Do not betray your uneasiness. We must endeavour to keep up her spirits, and allay her fears.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fetch my hood and cloak, Maria. I am going to the Convent of the Carmelites, She sometimes visits the sisters. (perceiving Claudio) Ah, Claudio! where is she?— what has happened to my dear mother? She has not been home since vespers! If any accident should have happened to her—if she should be dead!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Your love exaggerates your fears! She has been prevented by some unforeseen circumstance—some sudden indisposition, perhaps—from returning home; but she is safe; depend upon it, she is safe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Heaven grant your words prove true!—they have given me hope and courage!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A strange man, signora, requests to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A strange man! What is he like?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A genteel sort of ragamuffin, signora.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He may bring me intelligence of my mother. (to Servant) I will see him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And I will be near you, on the balcony, during this interview.
sp.stage: Claudio goes out on balcony at back—Maria exits, L.— and Hector Fiaramonti, conducted by a Servant who retires immediately, enters, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Approach, friend. You bring me intelligence of my mother, do you not?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: No, signora.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But you know where she is.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I regret I do not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why do you come here then?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Because I am a good-natured devil, whom most people would call a fool.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What is your business with me?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: To save you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p:
You are in danger; and if you will condescend to
accept advice from a stranger, of no very prepossessing exterior, let me counsel you not to go abroad unattended.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I never knew I had an enemy.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: An enemy? No!—that would be impossible! But there is a certain person here in Genoa, with gold at command, who has determined to separate you and Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: The name of this person?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Ah, signor! I didn't know you were a listener.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I have heard enough to make it necessary I should hear more. I require the name of this person by whom our future happiness is threatened.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I cannot give it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I request—I intreat you to do so; and if a liberal reward—

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Stop, signor!—it is impossible!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Take care! (touching his sword) I may make you speak!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I may be silent. Good night, signor.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stay, I beseech you— the Count was wrong; but his love for me must be his excuse.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Ah! true, true. You might be an excuse for almost anything. Count, you may reckon on me as your devoted servant from this hour. I will be your unseen but constant protector.

sp.speaker: Claud.
