sp.p: Thanks, my friend, I can defend myself when needful; but my dear Francisca, this secret enemy of whom you spoke has already perhaps struck a cruel blow at her happiness. The signora's mother has mysteriously disappeared.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: It must be that devil of a woman! I'll lay my life on it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah! your countenance tells me you know where she is.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: No signora, no. I swear I am ignorant of what has become of her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But you suspect?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And you will save her. I feel convinced that you can if you will. Ah, you will have pity on me.
sp.stage: (she falls on her knees at his feet)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Signora! This position—(aside) I never saw a woman on her knees to me before—it's too touching. (raising her) Rise, signora. Your mother shall be restored to you if I live.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Will you take me with you? I may be able to assist you.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: The offer of a good sword, and a courageous heart, should never be refused. I accept both—adieu, signora.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Adieu, Francisca, hope for the best; we will soon find your mother.
sp.stage: Claudio and Hector exeunt, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: His words give me courage, I will hope and trust to him. (Rudiga appears on the terrace outside the window at back, and is about to enter; stops as overcome at the sight of Francisca) My fears are past, and a thrill of joy runs through my veins as though my mother was there ready to clasp me to her heart.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: My child!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I wonder will they be long? No, no! I feel she will soon return. An invisible power attracts me, her presence seems to fill the air.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Neomi, Neomi!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It is I; fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You! (aside) That terrible woman, and I am alone with her. (calls) Maria!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Stop! for pity.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What do you want? Why do you pursue me! (retreating as Rudiga advances) Come no nearer, or I call for help.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Oh! No, no, no, I would not for the world's treasures hurt one of the silken hairs of your head. What have you to fear from a poor woman kneeling at your feet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How piteously she gazes at me through the tears that fill her eyes.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You do not fear me. Oh! say you do not fear me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do not. I pity you from my heart, for I see you have tasted misery.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Tasted! I have drank the bitter cup of misery to the dregs. Look at these wasted limbs, these hollow cheeks, this hair, once dark as the raven's wing, now grey and scant. Misery has done this. Misery has been my sole companion through life.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas! you have suffered much. Rise—pray rise; give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Thank!—thanks!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why do you gaze so earnestly at me? (Rudiga clasps her hands imploringly) You have some request to make. What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: What? (aside) Shall I tell her that I am her mother?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do not hesitate to confide in me—I can sympathise with your sufferings. Speak.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She might kill me by a word.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You doubt me perhaps?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: No, no; you have told me you pity me, and your words fell like heaven's music on my ears!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then speak to me as a friend.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Let me kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My hand?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: I had a daughter once, whom you resemble. She was stolen from me—stolen in infancy. When I look at you, I fancy I behold her; and if I might press your hand to my lips, I should be happy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: There. (giving her hand to Rudiga, who covers it with kisses—aside) Poor woman! How she must have loved her child. (to Rudiga) What was your daughter's name?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
Fran.
sp.p: Why do you not reclaim your daughter?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Because the tender plant which has so long lain in the bosom of the woman who calls herself her mother, may have taken root there; better to lose her for ever, than find the empty casket from which her love has been stolen by another.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But such a theft would be impossible. The voice of nature would have whispered to her, “she is not your mother.”

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Then, you do not love this woman?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What woman?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Pardon—pardon! I sometimes forget myself. I mean, if the Signora Donati were not your mother, would you love her?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The thought would kill me, for none other could I feel the affection that I owe to the fond parent who has watched over my tender years.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She has robbed me of that blessing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Night by night, kneeling beside the cradle of the pale being, whose life seemed fleeting away like a shadow, she struggled with death for his prey, and tore me from his icy grasp. It was more than a mother's tenderness; it was the devotion—the self-denial of an angel. You cannot know how dear she is to me.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It is thus she would have loved me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So kind, so gentle, and so beautiful as she is.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p:
Ah! Well may she be. Despair
and misery have not wrought their cruel defacement on her beauty. (aside—crosses to R.) She can never love me. (with forced calm) Adieu! signora, adieu!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stay!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: No; let me depart! You loath me; you shrink from the poor Jewess. Ha, ha, ha! The voice of Nature! There is no such thing—I laugh at it. Ha, ha, ha! Poor mother! To your grave, to your grave! They have been digging it for sixteen years; now 'tis ready to receive you. To your grave! where this poor broken heart will be at rest. Adieu, signora!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You shall not leave me. Your voice penetrates my heart, and agitates me with strange emotion. What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing. All I ask is that should we meet again in this world, you will not turn from me in contempt or horror. Promise that you will bestow a kind word or look upon me as you pass.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I promise you.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Again, I thank you. One last look and—(she pauses, looks at Francisca—she seems terribly agitated) Ah! I cannot leave her; my heart-strings would break.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: In heaven's name, what does this terrible struggle mean?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It means—Neomi—I am your mother. (Francisca utters an exclamation of affright, and retreats from Rudiga) You are the child who were stolen from me in infancy. This bosom gave thee life. Shrink not from me, Neomi! I am not what I seem. You know me only as Rudiga, the Woman in Red, the sybil—the magician; but I am also Rudiga, the millionaire—whose wealth can purchase for you fifty mansions, more magnificent than the one you quit. What do you desire? A palace with floors of marble—columns of alabaster—gardens like those of Babylon—fountains sparkling with water sweeter than the brooks of Hebron—all that your wildest imagination can picture, shall be yours. Oh! you shall own that I am indeed your mother—come, come, come!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas, grief has disturbed her reason.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Come—Neomi, come. Does not that name make your heart thrill? come.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to-morrow. There will be time enough to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: To-morrow—Ah! she, too, believes I am mad.
sp.stage: (sinks into an arm chair, which conceals her from the view of Constanza Donati, who enters C. followed by Claudio and Hector.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.stage: (perceiving Constanza, throws herself into her arms)
sp.p: Ah, mother!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My dear Francisca.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your absence nearly killed me. What happened to you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: An accident, I was in danger, but 'tis past; let us not talk of it now. Matte the bird-catcher, and his wife, your protegés, were conducting me home, when we met Claudio and this stranger.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Allow me to introduce myself, Hector Fiaramonti, always at the service of the ladies. (to Francisca) I promised you, signora, that your mother should soon be restored to you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am safe now, and I hold you again in my arms, my child.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Your child?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ah, you?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Diavolo.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What brings this woman here? You know her, signora.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Do not ask me, but let us fly from Genoa, (winding her arm round Francisca) this very hour.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Constanza Donati. You may go, but she goes not with you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Call the servants, and let that maniac be turned into the street.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: And I'll order the carriage. You have no time to lose, you must quit Genoa to-night. That woman has the power of gold, and she will use it too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mother, why does she look at you so strangely. (aside) Ah! if she spoke truly—and that I am—no, no, it cannot be. (to Constanza) Tell me that you are indeed my mother.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You hear what she demands, Signora?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh, heaven!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah, your tears and silence fill me with terror. Am I for ever lost to you? Shall my heart which rested so peacefully upon yours, until they seemed to beat with but one pulse, be torn from you?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: How she loves her!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Look at me—clasp me closer. Do not these embraces and kisses prove that I am yours?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You are—you are—my child!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Swear that she is your child!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Woman—woman!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Swear, signora—and let the world be witness of your oath.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You can save me, mother; swear that I am your child—you will—you will.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.stage: (producing the gold cross which Francisca wore in the first act)
sp.p: Swear before heaven—on the symbol of your faith—swear on this cross! (holds the cross towards Constanza) See, 'tis the one which she wore on her spotless bosom this morning. (Constanza, who has raised her hand and advanced firmly towards Rudiga, stops) Swear—and be a perjured woman!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mother!—Mother!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No! (pointing to Rudiga) Behold your mother!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: There's a splendid equipage waiting in the courtyard; but it is not the Countess Donati's carriage.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It is mine. Come, Neomi, you can now accompany your mother.
sp.stage: (she gives her hand to Francisca, who takes it mechanically)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have been so long her daughter, that it is not easy to part thus. I would embrace her once more before I go.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Do—do.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My tongue must no more call you mother, but my heart will ever know you by that tender name. Farewell!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Francisca—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Claudio, adieu! (Rudiga places herself between Claudio and Francisca) I obey you, mother.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: No embrace for me.

div.stage: (at door, L., sinking overwhelmed with grief in a chair—the Characters group as the act drop descends)

div.head: ACT III. VENICE.
div.stage: Scene.—A Noble Saloon on the ground floor of a Palace on the Grand Canal, in Venice, with a view of the Island and Church of San Georgio; the saloon is richly and elegantly furnished; the back forms a semi-circle of light arches, closed by heavy scarlet curtains which may be withdrawn; and afford a view of a terrace, with a balustrade overlooking the canal; the terrace is decorated with statues, flowers in vases, and birds in gilt cages; the curtains are drawn at the commencement.
Matte dressed as the Intendant of Madame Montalba appears to be giving orders to two Stewards in rich liveries—enter Ninetta in travelling costume—Servants exeunt.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Hah, Ninetta, are you arrived, and is Madame Montalba come with you?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Yes, we're here, just arrived, with ever so much money; for madame has taken a fancy that the Signora Francisca shall not see this new palace, till it bursts suddenly upon her. So she has brought her here blindfolded in a gondola.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: What a strange idea! Well, I hope she'll be satisfied with my exertions. She sent me here from Trieste ten days ago, with orders to spare no cost in the newly purchased palazzo of hers, the most splendid in Venice, and I flatter myself I've obeyed her instructions to the letter. How do you like it, Ninetta?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: I never saw anything so beautiful—never! Why it must have cost Madame Rudiga, or as she is now called, Madame Montalba, a mint of money.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: She intends to surprise Signora Francisca. You know this is her birth-day, and this palazzo is to be her mother's present.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Such a mother never was; she only thinks of gratifying every wish of her daughter's heart. You know when she discovered that Signora Francisca was her child and she took her from Signora Donati, the young signora wished that I should accompany them when they left Genoa on their travels.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Ninetta, it was I whom the signora desired should be taken into their service.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Well, perhaps she was grateful to you for the service you rendered the Signora Donati that night in the street.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Yes; and when Madame Montalba proposed that I should accept the office of intendant in her family with a magnificent salary, I replied—

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Matte, it was I who replied, “Matte, madame, never travels without his wife.”

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Ah, quite right. So when I was installed as intendant to the mother—you were engaged as waiting-woman to the daughter—while your seven little bird-catchers were left in the care of my mother till our return.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Ah! and now here we are in Italy again—after having travelled half over Europe in twelve months. Are you not happy, Matte, to feel we are drawing near our little ones again, thought 'tis still a long way from Venice to Genoa.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Dear Genoa! I wonder do the birds sing as sweetly there as when I used to coax them to my net? Ah, I dare say they have nobody to catch them now—nobody like Matte Twitti; and the pretty girls too, what flocks of them used to come fluttering at my call!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: There, don't be prating like a magpie, or you'll have nothing prepared to receive our mistress.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Ah—true! and there's fifty things still to do. Here, Paulo—Marco—Pietro!—here! Where have the idle dogs got to?

sp.speaker: Hector

lg.l: I hear the patter of her feet,
As she comes tripping down the street;
Cara mio, cara mio,
Cara, cara, ah, carissima!

sp.p: Heaven is propitious to my wish—Ninetta!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Bless me—'tis Hector Fiaramonti! Oh! I'm so glad to see you! Why, you're not a bit altered since I saw you in Genoa twelve months ago! How did you know I was in Venice? When did you leave Genoa? How are all our friends, and what brings you here?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Briefly and categorically—I am infinitely obliged to you. I had information you were returned to Italy. I left Genoa six days ago. Our friends are pretty much as usual. I was brought here partly by land and principally by water, and beg to now offer you my profound respects. (bows) Signor Twitti, I trust, is well—quite well?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Never was better.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: And Madame Montalba and her daughter—how do they agree in their new relationship?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Wonderfully! Never did mother love a daughter so tenderly, and never did daughter repay a mother's affection with such dutiful observance; but—

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hah!—there is a “but?”

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Perhaps I ought not to mention it; but I fancy that neither of them are quite happy.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Madame Montalba perceives that, notwithstanding all her endeavours to direct her daughter's mind from the past, the poor girl's thoughts dwell continually upon it. I often find her in tears over a miniature which she carries in her bosom. One day I got a peep at it over her shoulder, and whose do you think it was?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Not mine.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Yours? Count Claudio's! There—she loves him still!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: By Jove! I'd run a man through the body with pleasure for such a girl as that!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: But trying to conceal her unhappiness from her mother, the poor soul grows paler and thinner every day.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: And Madame Montalba?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: It is still worse with her. By day she struggles to conceal her feelings, and appear gay and cheerful; but at night—at night—(mysteriously) Have you ever known any one who walked in her sleep?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Yes, I remember when I was a boy, I used to frequently walk in my sleep to a neighbouring orchard, and when I awoke in the morning, I generally found my bolster case full of apples.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Well, Madame Montalba is what they call a somnambulist, and when her mind is much disturbed, she comes at night like a spectre from her chamber, with those great dark eyes of hers wide open, though she is fast asleep; and then all the strange and terrible scenes of her life seem to pass through her brain, and are acted over again. Ah! the poor woman has suffered as you have never suffered. We take care though that Signora Francisca never sees her in this state, it would shock her so, but mark my words, this dreadful struggle will kill one or both of them, if it lasts much longer.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Then why not end it?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Can you tell how it is to be done?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Certainly. By restoring the girl to those whom she has loved from infancy.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: That can never be. Madame Montalba lives but in her daughter's presence; to part with her for a single day would kill her.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: But others suffer as she does: Signora Donati and Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Yes; it must have been a dreadful trial to them to part with her.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p:
I don't make a boast of my fine feelings, but I
protest I was touched to see how the count wasted from day to day till there was only a shadow left of him,

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Ah! I pity the poor young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Do you? Then it is in your power to mitigate his grief, by conveying this letter from him to the signora.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Impossible! Madame Montalba has strictly forbidden any private correspondence with her daughter.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Consider the peculiarity of the case. Picture to yourselves two fond lovers torn asunder.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: It's shocking; but I can't.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Realize the highly dramatic situation of their agonising farewell.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: It brings tears to my eyes.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Think of the pangs of absence.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: They're cruel, I know.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Imagine the distracted lover, sending a letter to his heart's idol by a faithful hand; fancy the joy which the sight of it will bring to the disconsolate lady; how the colour will come back to her cheek, and the smile to her lip, when she learns that her lover is at this moment in Venice!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Count Claudio in Venice?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: With Signora Donati, to whom he has been all that an affectionate son could be, since her husband died last year a bankrupt at Barcelona.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Heaven bless him for his goodness.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: You'll take the letter then?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: I will. She shall have it, whatever comes of it. (Hector gives her the letter) Then you had better get away as fast as you can. I hear Madame Montalba's voice. (Hector is going off, R.) No, not that way, she might meet you and suspect something. You must go by the private staircase (at door, R.) at the end of the gallery. A door at the foot of the stairs on the canal, here's the key; when you have got outside you can lock the door and slip the key under it. (gives Hector key) Now go.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Lucky chance! Adieu. Compassionate dove, adieu!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Hah! There was not a moment to lose.
sp.stage: Enter Rudiga, L, leading Francisca with one hand, while with the other she covers her daughter's eyes.

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: You must not look yet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Where are you leading me?

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: A moment more and you shall know.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: How she plays the child for her!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: Another step. (Francisca has now gained the centre of the stage—the curtains at the back are withdrawn, and the spectators see the terrace of the Palazzo adorned with flowers in boxes and vases, statues and birds in gilt cages beyond the calm waters of the lagune, upon which the setting sun casts its beams—Rudiga removing her hand from Francisca) Now, look around.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh! what a beautiful place.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It is yours.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine. This fairy palace?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Is my birthday present, to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah! you remembered it was my birthday. (runs to back, and looks out on the terrace) All my favourite flowers are here, the birds I love, and the statues I admire. (coming down) You have thought of everything that could delight me. (embracing Rudiga) You are too good to me.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: This embrace repays me for all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah! what a magnificent scene. But surely, I have beheld it before, that sea, that shore, that island, and its ancient church—Have I dreamed of this enchanting picture—Ah! no, no, I now remember it, every familiar object returns to me like the faces of old friends.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You know it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Perfectly, ten years ago, when I was but a child, I passed a month in this Palazzo with my mother.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Your mother!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With the Signora Donati, we were returning to Genoa from Vienna. Here on this terrace, I remember we use to sit in the golden light of evening, the waters of the broad lagune spreading like a mirror before us, while the chant of the gondolier floated around us on the perfume-laden air.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Amongst these happy memories there is no place for me.
sp.stage: (the song of a gondolier is heard at a distance)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hark! listen to that melody.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: It comes from yonder gondola; that one with blue silk curtains which approaches the terrace, like a wild sea bird on the wing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis the song that lulled me to sleep in infancy, when I lay upon the bosom of one who was mother.
sp.stage: (a gondola glides on at back from L., Constanza Donati is seen standing in prow)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: A lady stands in the gondola waving her handkerchief.
sp.stage: (Francisca looks eagerly towards the gondola, and recognises Constanza at the same moment with Rudiga—both start and utter a suppressed exclamation)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: 'Tis Constanza Donati.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My heart flies to embrace her.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She has recognised her.
sp.stage: (the gondola passes to R. and disappears, the song gradually dies away)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The bark glides past—the song dies upon the waves like the dreams of happy childhood.
sp.stage: (night begins to fall, and lights to appear in the houses and church on the Island of Saint Georgio—gondolas with lanterns on their prows shoot hither and thither on the lagune—Francisca remains absorbed in thought near the terrace)

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: That woman comes again to cast her shadow on my path. Is it not horrible, they will not leave a daughter to her mother. They robbed me of her for sixteen years, and now they count the minutes while she is near me. (looking at Francisca) Her soul is with them now. (resolutely) I must recall it. Enter Ninetta, R. Give me the casket from that cabinet. (gives Ninetta a key— she unlocks the cabinet, takes out an antique casket) These gems, the glittering wrecks of fallen royalty, will captivate her fancy. (takes a diamond necklace from the casket, which Ninetta holds for her) Look, Neomi, here. (Francisca comes down) How do you like this necklace?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Superb! What splendid diamonds.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: And this coronet, in which the artist's hand has copied those wild flowers so skilfully?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A matchless work, indeed!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: You shall put them on, Francisca; I want to judge their beauty near to yours. Assist me, Ninon, 'twill be done in a moment. (Ninetta assists Rudiga, who puts the various ornaments on Francisca) Do not move, my child; there, there, 'tis finished.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Oh, madame, has she not the air of a queen?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.stage: (taking a hand mirror from the cabinet, holds it to Francisca)
sp.p: Are you satisfied with your lady's maid? Has she succeeded in her task?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Marvellously! For whom is this magnificent present intended?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: For you. Another birthday offering from a fond and doting mother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For me! Oh, 'tis too much, you overwhelm me with your gifts. How shall I fitly thank you?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: By loving me with all your heart.
sp.stage: (Francisca is about to throw herself into Rudiga's arms, when the song as before is heard approaching, R.— Francisca stops, listens eagerly, and forgetful of all around her, is attracted towards the terrace)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That song—that voice—again!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Neomi!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: They are approaching.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: She hears me not. (the gondola of Signora Donati slides on from R.; it is brilliantly illuminated, and by the strong light, Constanza, Claudio and Hector are seen in the gondola) She has no eyes—no ears—no thought for me.
sp.stage: (sinks beside a chair and hides her face in it, in an agony of grief)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.stage: (leaning over the balustrade of the terrace)
sp.p: Gentle wind, bear this kiss to her who was my mother.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: This struggle with relentless fate will kill me. I feel the fabric of my hopes crumbling to its fall. I will not try to stay it another day—no, not an hour; let it come and crush me in its ruins; she shall leave me—leave me for this woman whom she loves, and then abandoned by her, death will soon come to release me from my misery. (rises) Where is she? (perceives Francisca on the terrace) Still there, charmed by the spell that holds her from my heart. (looking towards the balcony, but unperceived by Francisca) Neomi! beloved Neomi!—child of my youth—sole beauteous blossom of my love! though cruel hands have dug a gulf between my heart and thine, I bless thee—bless thee, evermore, my child!
sp.stage: Exit in a passion of tears, R.
Francisca re-enters from the balcony at the same time that Ninetta enters, L.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, this double love tears my heart asunder. How nature draws me to the mother who bore me; these long cherished memories hold me to her who was to me in all but blood, my mother. Why cannot I keep them both for ever near me—press them together to my heart, and mingle my affections with their love. But no, the world and its prejudices must for ever divide us.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Signora. (Francisca turns) Bless me! how those diamonds flash and sparkle—like stars!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Poor stars! that cannot cast one ray of hope upon my darkened path. Take them, Ninetta—take
them from my sight!
sp.stage: (she tears off the necklace, bracelets, and coronet—Ninetta takes them)

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: I thought, signora, that you might be pleased—that is that you might not be angry—at my bringing you this letter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: From Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: From Claudio? Hush! (takes the letter) Oh, thanks—thanks!—a thousand times!
sp.stage: (she goes up to terrace and reads the letter, while Ninetta places the jewels in the cabinet which she locks)

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: That letter will make her happy for to-night at least.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, Ninetta! he has not forgotten me—he loves me still. Claudio and my mother, they both love their poor Francisca! (mysteriously) I saw them this evening, Ninetta, in a gondola beneath the terrace; but, alas! I may never see them again!
sp.stage: Enter Hector, R., unperceived, while she speaks.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Permit me to assure you to the contrary, signora.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Goodness!—how did you get in?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: You forgot the key of the door on the canal which you intrusted to me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I remember your face: you are a friend of Count Claudio's. What brings you here?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: My good nature, which leads me everywhere. I promised Count Claudio and the Signora Donati that they should have an interview with you this evening; and I have kept my word—they are here.
sp.stage: Enter Constanza and Claudio, C.—the former flies to embrace Francisca.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My child!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mother!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Francisca!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Claudio! (giving him her hand, which he kisses) This was my birthday, and you are here to comfort me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You need comfort, then? My dear child! are you not happy?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Oh! yes, yes—I am happy! I ought to be happy, for she loves me dearly as mother loves her child. But I fear I am ungrateful. She asks affection for her tenderness; I can only give respect. Yet sometimes when I see her weeping alone, suspecting not that any eye beholds her, I feel a strange
emotion struggling in my bosom. Ah! let us talk no more of this. Tell me something that concerns yourself—your health —your travels—of your friends in Genoa. We will sit and converse together here by the light of pale stars.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Not here, signora, if you please. Your mother sleeps in the next room. (points to L.) In the saloon on this side, you will be secure from interruption.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are right, Ninetta—lead the way for us.
sp.stage: Exeunt, L. Ninetta, Constanza and Claudio—Hector remains.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I think they can dispense with my company, so I'll amuse myself with my pipe on the terrace till they return. (takes his pipe from his pocket, and about lighting it) Friends forsake us, women deceive us, but a pipe consoles us when we have nothing left in the world. (perceives Bravadura who has climbed up to the balustrades of the terrace, and is getting over) Holloa! who this strange visitor? Somebody who don't care to disturb the porter.
sp.stage: (Bravadura crosses the terrace, and enters the saloon at back, Hector conceals himself behind a high-backed chair and watches)

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: All quiet here, not a mouse stirring.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Bravadura!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: This rich Jewess, I hear carries about with her heaps of plate, jewels, money; could I but discover her hoard—I'd relieve her of the care of so much superfluous wealth.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Disinterested rascal!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Ha! This old cabinet here promises well—I'll take the liberty of seeing what it contains. (produces skeleton keys) Open its jaws.
sp.stage: (working at the lock of the cabinet)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Not so fast, my amiable friend. (comes softly behind Bravadura, and slaps him on the shoulder) Always industrious, Bravadura.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.stage: (starts and clasps his hand to his dagger)
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Stop! Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Why it's Hector Fiaramonti.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Sorry to interrupt your interesting work.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Oh! never mind. I suppose we're on the same business. Ah, well—there's enough for both.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Quite enough!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: We'll go shares in the plunder—that's fair, isn't it.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Perfectly fair—the only objection to this pleasant arrangement is—that I've become an honest man.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p:
Honest! Ha! ha! ha! You shouldn't make me
laugh. Honest! ha! ha! We're all honest when we have no temptation to roguery—but we waste time, I've nearly got the lock of this cabinet open. (looking at the lock of cabinet) It isn't for nothing such locks as these are made—but it shan't baffle Bravadura.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: My dear friend, your skill and energy are wonderful. If nature had not made you a burglar, you'd have been a prime minister; but you must desist from your operations, and instantly quit this house.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Quit the house. What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: That you must go—without accomplishing the object of your visit.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Ah! you want to have the job all yourself, but you shan't, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: March this moment.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: He shall taste my steel first. Hold! Do you not see a figure moving on the terrace?
sp.stage: (draws his dagger, and is about to stab Hector, who perceives the action in a mirror, turns suddenly, seizes Bravadura's arm, wrests the dagger from him, and flings it down)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Burglar! You forgot the mirror.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: No matter. (clock strikes twelve) One of us must find the bottom of the canal before that clock has done striking.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hah (they struggle—Hector is forced by Bravadura towards the terrace) Ah! his grasp is like iron. Ah!— help, there, help!—hah!
sp.stage: Enter Claudio, L., at the moment Bravadura has got Hector on terrace.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Holloa! what means this alarm? Hold, there!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Count—Count Claudio! Help!—hah!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Hector—I am here!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Fiends seize the fool! The odds are too many for me.
sp.stage: (he attempts to get away, but is intercepted by Claudio)

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Stop!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Don't let him escape—he came to rob the house.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Rob?—me rob? Nothing of the sort. I merely called when passing to inquire after the health of Victor Sanson—my old friend, companion, (aside to Hector) and accomplice.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: You should not have reminded me of that. Count Claudio, I denounce that man as the murderer of your mother!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Ah, villain! Have I found you at last?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hubert Malisset and we have a long account to settle.

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Two swords against one? (draws his sword) Brave fellows you are!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Stand aside, Hector. Leave him to me. The assassin of my mother shall fall by no hand but mine!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Show mercy to a rat—well!

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Fool! (aloud) We are on equal ground now. (half aside) 'Tis my last chance in the game of life;— I'll play it out like a desperate man.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Ha! Well, thrust, Count. Ha, ha, ha! He's young and vigorous, and—ah!— that infernal lunge of Hubert's! Ah!—my fingers itch to be at him. Well guarded—ha! There!—bravo!—bravo! Press him—press him, Count! He gives way! Viva!
sp.stage: (leaps with delight as Claudio disarms and wounds Bravadura—the latter sinks to his knee)

sp.speaker: Brava.
sp.p: Malediction! (he finds the dagger on the floor Hector had flung away—aside) Ha! my dagger!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Hurrah, hurrah!
sp.stage: (Bravadura rushes furiously on Claudio, who receives him on his sword, and passes it through his body— Bravadura flings up his arms and stands erect— Claudio withdraws his sword, and Bravadura falls dead)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Dead as a stockfish. 'Twas a sharp bout while it lasted.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: My mother is avenged!
sp.stage: (they raise the body, and carry it to terrace at back)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: He wasn't pleasant to look at when living, and death hasn't improved his looks. There, that's a load of my mind, and now I'll go and smoke my pipe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We grew uneasy at your absence, Claudio; hearing a noise we feared some danger.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I was obliged to use a little force to expel an intruder, that was all.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: It grows late, my dear child, and we must leave; but we will come again, and you will accompany us to the house where your happy days of childhood were passed.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Your lute lies untouched, your songs unsung; the birds that answered to your voice are mute, the flowers you
planted want your tendering hand—(apart to her tenderly) and the heart that loves you best, mourns till you return.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Claudio! Mother! urge me no more. Heaven knows how dear to me you are; but the holier duty which I owe to her who gave me life commands me not to leave her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And whose the greater sacrifice, the mother whose short pangs, the penalty of nature, are forgotten soon, or she who in the pride of youth and beauty, surrounded by the world's delights and its allurements, left them all to watch and pray beside the cradle of thy suffering infancy, giving her very life to purchase thine?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Think you I ever can forget your love.
sp.stage: (Ninetta who has been listening at door, R. approaches them hastily)

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: Signora, signora! Your friends must leave you. Madame Montalba is moving in her chamber—I heard her. Pray let them go directly.
sp.stage: Enter Rudiga from room, R.; asleep in white dishabille, she carries her scarlet cloak on her arm.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She is here—she will see you.

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: No, she is asleep.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Asleep?

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Look, Reuben, down there in the valley—the cottage that holds our treasure, her arms are stretching forth to clasp me. Ah! Marguerite, I am here. Kind, good Marguerite, where is my child—my Neomi? We are rich now. Where? Ah! here in her cradle.
sp.stage: (she goes through the action of drawing back the curtains of the cradle, and of her alarm on discovering the Child is not there—action of seeking everywhere for the Child)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, this is dreadful!

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: I have seen her often thus. She now fancies herself in Marguerite D'Arbel's cottage the day you were carried off.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: What have you done with her? Speak, woman, or I will tear the secret from your heart! (catching as at some person) Still silent! in pity then, (sinks on her knees and raises her hands in a supplicating attitude) you will tell me— you will. (starts suddenly to her feet with a cry) Hah! shot— shot, Marguerite! She is dying—one word—but one! (with horror) No, no—she is dead! dead!
sp.stage: (she sinks on the floor overpowered by the shock)

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My poor mother.
sp.stage: (she is about to rush to Rudiga, but is withheld by Ninetta)

sp.speaker: Ninet.
sp.p: To wake her suddenly, would kill her.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.stage:
(slowly rising—her features and actions are expressive
of solemn resolve)
sp.p: All—all are gone! Reuben dead, Marguerite dead, Neomi lost. Alone then, I will seek my child— the world is all before me. (she takes the scarlet cloak from the floor, and throws it over her shoulders: then passes rapidly from side to side of the stage, and everywhere appears to be driven back) Ah, repulsed—driven from every door with curses. Hark, that yell! (terrified) The people pursue me like ravening wolves, with savage cries—“thief,” “spy,” “sorceress.” (runs wildly to and fro—as if pursued by a mob—and at last falls exhausted on the earth) Mercy! mercy! ah, there is no mercy for me, none, none, chains and tortures—chains and tortures for the vile Jewess. (remains for a few moments silent, with her head bent to the earth) But the daugher of Israel rises like the cedar on her own hills, above her wrongs. (rising grandly) The book of fate is open to me—the cards speak the truth, (she spread her mantle on the ground) come all—and learn from me the secrets of the future. (she expresses by action, spreading out a pack of cards on her mantle) Press not upon me—more room. Hah! (starts as perceiving some person) Ha! that face—there—there—the girl Neomi—'tis she, my child—my long-lost one. Ah! who stands between me and her—that woman. She is not her mother—no— restore her to me, give me back the child you have stolen, she is mine—mine! (tenderly) Neomi, they shall never tear thee from these arms again—never! Take my hand, and let us quit Genoa. Oh! I am happy now! my child, come—come.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She thinks only of me.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Lay thy head here—upon my breast, my Neomi— my treasure upon earth—my life. When you were an infant, I held you thus.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mother, dearest mother!

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Ah, your eyes are turned from mine! What do they seek? Ah, wretched mother! her heart still clings to that woman, and she has no love for me—none. (she sinks into a chair) The tender flower would wither in this breast. It must not be. There is no way but one, she shall leave me, and return to her whom she has learned to love. Go, Neomi! go quickly—while I have strength to part with you. With me you never could be happy. Heed not my tears; their channels have been worn by long years of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ah, 'twas my selfishness that wrought this misery!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If I might but kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: Once, ere we part for ever, let me embrace thee, my child.
sp.stage:
(she extends her arms, and Francisca with a cry throws herself on her mother's breast—Rudiga starts up and
awakes)
sp.p: Hah, Neomi! What is this? in my arms—on my heart; I have been dreaming. Am I dreaming still?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, dearest mother; till now, I never knew the strength of a mother's love. I am yours, alone! alone!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Happy mother! (Rudiga perceiving her, starts in terror and places herself between Constanza and Francisca) Fear nothing, madam, from me. I now understand what your sufferings have been, and I deeply repent the share I had in their cause. Say that you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: The past is a dark gulf, in which I have buried my hatred with my griefs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cast into it the prejudices that divide two noble hearts. Are you not both my mothers—in— the love you bear me—both sisters by the sacrifices you have made for your child.

sp.speaker: Rudig.
sp.p: We shall love her better united.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Madame, I thank you fervently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Heaven has heard my prayers, and if—

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: A name trembles on your lips—“Claudio.” Your heart cleaves to him—take him—love him—he is worthy of you.
sp.stage: (Claudio crosses to Francisca and kisses her hand)

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: A life's devotion shall prove my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Rudiga.
sp.p: And you who have pitied the sufferings, and felt for the wrongs of the poor Jewess,—rejoice with her now, for she has subdued all, suffered all, and gained all by the powerful magic of a Mother's Love.
